metadata.synopsis: Katja's life falls apart in the blink of an eye when two neo-Nazis kill her husband and 6-year-old son in a bomb attack. Her quest for justice soon pushes her to the edge as the two suspects stand trial for murder.

reviews: "In the Fade" could have been something remarkable were it not for the wearisome slog it becomes in the middle. Even with a compelling conclusion, it never fully recovers.
If you've ever doubted Kruger's ability to carry a film, In the Fade should put your doubts to rest.
As a courtroom thriller, In the Fade delivers.

Squarely told with its moral outrage worn plainly on the sleeve, In the Fade is not a particularly artful movie. That said, there's something about the blunt emotionality it speaks in the face of deadly extremist aggression that feels sadly appropriate.
It is an interesting author's film within the revenge thriller genre. [Full Review in Spanish]
Akin takes us through the intense events of the film in a deliberate, almost businesslike way.
When Katja Sekerci learns of the deaths of her Turkish husband and their six-year-old son in a nail-bomb explosion at the Sekercis' Hamburg office, she reacts with the scream of a stricken animal.
The upswing in Nationalist sympathy and homegrown terrorism are framed by a mother's grief and quest for vengeance.
This powerful, troubling, and topically relevant narrative is a triumph, with Kruger giving a powerhouse performance that tops most -- if not all -- performances seen on the [2018] award circuit.
Its mature and delicate exploration of human emotion makes it a moving watch, and it avoids the trap of excessive sentimentality or violence in its portrayal of a survivor yearning for justice.
There are unique moments, to be fair: they are just spaced far apart in this predictable, paint by numbers story.
... conceived with strong performances... never softens up, even when giving signs of momentarily wobbling.

Fatih Akin's attempt to dramatise the shocking realities of far right terrorism is at least commendable on paper, but the muddled execution ensures that that the limited emotional impact it does have will only continue to fade over time.
It's no mistake that Kruger won Best Actress at Cannes because her Katja is a force.
It cleverly incriminates societal assumptions.
In The Fade somehow manages to surpass the limitations of its own storyline.
Meant to be a blunt object against the recent tide of nationalism and racist ideologies, but it's almost completely ineffective at achieving those goals.
In The Fade is a challenging movie to sit through just based on its content, but it's beautifully composed cinematography and phenomenal performances make it the challenges worth it.
It's not a perfect movie... still there is an unanswerable force to this angry, unblinking depiction of the consequences of far-right violence in Europe today.
In the Fade is never less than gripping.
